{{multiple image | header = Sudarsky classification as used on ''[[Celestia]].'' | width = 150 | direction = vertical | image1 = Celestia exo-class1.png | alt1 = Class I gas giant | caption1 = Class I | image2 = Celestia exo-class2.png | alt2 = Class II gas giant | caption2 = Class II | image3 = Celestia exo-class3.png | alt3 = Class III gas giant | caption3 = Class III | image4 = Celestia exo-class4.png | alt4 = Class IV gas giant | caption4 = Class IV | image5 = Celestia exo-class5.png | alt5 = Class V gas giant | caption5 = Class V }}
'''Sudarsky's classification of gas giants''' for the purpose of predicting their appearance based on their temperature was outlined by [[David Sudarsky]] and colleagues in the paper ''Albedo and Reflection Spectra of Extrasolar Giant Planets''<ref name="sudarsky">{{cite journal |url=http://www.iop.org/EJ/abstract/0004-637X/538/2/885/|author=Sudarsky, D.|author2=Burrows, A.|author3=Pinto, P.|title=Albedo and Reflection Spectra of Extrasolar Giant Planets|journal=[[The Astrophysical Journal]] | volume=538 | date=2000 | pages=885–903 | doi=10.1086/309160 | bibcode=2000ApJ...538..885S|arxiv = astro-ph/9910504 | issue=2}}</ref> and expanded on in ''Theoretical Spectra and Atmospheres of Extrasolar Giant Planets'',<ref name="sudarsky2">{{cite journal | author=Sudarsky, D. | author2=Burrows, A. | author3=Hubeny, I. | title=Theoretical Spectra and Atmospheres of Extrasolar Giant Planets | journal=[[The Astrophysical Journal]] | date=2003 | volume=588 | issue=2 | pages=1121–1148 | doi=10.1086/374331 | bibcode=2003ApJ...588.1121S|arxiv = astro-ph/0210216 }}</ref> published before any successful direct or indirect observation of an extrasolar planet atmosphere was made. It is a broad classification system with the goal of bringing some order to the likely rich variety of extrasolar gas-giant atmospheres.
[[Gas giant]]s are split into five classes (numbered using [[Roman numerals]]) according to their modeled physical atmospheric properties. In the Solar System, only [[Jupiter]] and [[Saturn]] are within the Sudarsky classification, and both are Class I. The appearance of planets that are not gas giants cannot be predicted by the Sudarsky system, for example [[terrestrial planet]]s such as [[Earth]] and [[Venus]], [[HD 85512 b]] (3.6 [[Earth mass]]es) and [[OGLE-2005-BLG-390Lb]] (5.5 Earth masses), or [[ice giant]]s such as [[Uranus]] (14 Earth masses) and [[Neptune]] (17 Earth masses).
== Background == The appearance of extrasolar planets is largely unknown because of the difficulty in making direct observations of [[extrasolar planets]]. In addition, analogies with planets in the [[Solar System]] can apply for few of the extrasolar planets known; because most are wholly unlike any of our planets, for example the [[hot Jupiter]]s.
Bodies that transit their star can be spectrographically mapped, for instance [[HD 189733 b]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spitzer.caltech.edu/Media/releases/ssc2007-09/ssc2007-09a.shtml |title=First Map of Alien World |accessdate=November 23, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071016161601/http://www.spitzer.caltech.edu/Media/releases/ssc2007-09/ssc2007-09a.shtml |archivedate=October 16, 2007 }}</ref> That planet has further been shown to be blue with an [[albedo]] greater (brighter) than 0.14.<ref name="Berdyugina">{{cite journal | url=http://www.astro.phys.ethz.ch/papers/berdyugina/exoplanet_hd189733b.pdf | journal=The Astrophysical Journal | volume=673 | issue=1 | date=20 January 2008 | title=First detection of polarized scattered light from an exoplanetary atmosphere | first=Svetlana V. | last=Berdyugina | author2=Andrei V. Berdyugin | author3=Dominique M. Fluri | author4=Vilppu Piirola | doi=10.1086/527320 | pages=L83 | bibcode=2008ApJ...673L..83B | arxiv=0712.0193 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081217111141/http://www.astro.phys.ethz.ch/papers/berdyugina/exoplanet_hd189733b.pdf | archivedate=17 December 2008 | df= }}</ref> Most transiting planets are hot Jupiters.
Speculation on the appearances of ''unseen'' extrasolar planets currently relies upon computational models of the likely [[atmosphere]] of such a planet, for instance how the atmospheric temperature–pressure profile and composition would respond to varying degrees of [[insolation]].
== Planetary classes ==
=== Class I: Ammonia clouds === {{multiple image | width = 200 | direction = vertical | image1 = Jupiter.jpg | image2 = Saturn_Equinox_09212014.jpg | footer = [[Jupiter]] and [[Saturn]], two Sudarsky class I gas giants. }} Planets in this class have appearances dominated by [[ammonia]] clouds. These planets are found in the outer regions of a [[planetary system]]. They exist at temperatures less than about {{convert|150|K|C F|sigfig=2}}. The predicted Bond [[albedo]] of a class I planet around a [[star]] like the [[Sun]] is 0.57, compared with a value of 0.343 for [[Jupiter]]<ref>[http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/planetary/factsheet/jupiterfact.html Jupiter Fact Sheet<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> and 0.342 for [[Saturn]].<ref>[http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/planetary/factsheet/saturnfact.html Saturn Fact Sheet<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The discrepancy can be partially accounted for by taking into account non-equilibrium condensates such as [[tholin]]s or [[phosphorus]], which are responsible for the coloured clouds in the Jovian atmosphere, and are not modelled in the calculations.
The temperatures for a class I planet require a cool star or a distant orbit. The former stars might be too dim for us even to know about them, and the latter orbits might be too unpronounced for notice until several observations of those ''orbits''' "years" (cf. [[Kepler's laws of planetary motion#Third law|Kepler's third law]]). [[Superjovian]]s would have enough mass to improve these observations; but a superjovian of comparable age to Jupiter will have more [[internal heat]]ing than said planet, which could push it to a higher class.
As of 2015, [[47 Ursae Majoris c]] and [[47 Ursae Majoris d|d]] could be Class I planets. [[Upsilon Andromedae e]] and [[55 Cancri d]] may also be Class I planets.
=== Class II: Water clouds === Planets in class II are too warm to form ammonia clouds; instead their clouds are made up of [[water vapor]]. These characteristics are expected for planets with temperatures below around 250 K (-23°C; -10°F).<ref name="sudarsky2" /> Water clouds are more reflective than ammonia clouds, and the predicted Bond albedo of a class II planet around a Sun-like star is 0.81. Even though the clouds on such a planet would be similar to those of [[Earth]], the atmosphere would still consist mainly of [[hydrogen]] and hydrogen-rich molecules such as [[methane]].
Examples of possible class II planets: [[HD 45364 b]] and [[HD 45364 c]], [[HD 28185 b]], [[Gliese 876 b]] and [[Gliese 876 c|c]], [[Upsilon Andromedae d]], [[55 Cancri f]], [[47 Ursae Majoris b]], [[PH2b]], [[Kepler-90 h]], [[HD 10180 g]].
=== Class III: Cloudless === Planets with equilibrium temperatures between about 350 K (170 °F, 80 °C) and 800 K (980 °F, 530 °C) do not form global cloud cover, because they lack suitable chemicals in the atmosphere to form clouds.<ref name="sudarsky2" /> These planets would appear as featureless azure-blue globes because of [[Rayleigh scattering]] and absorption by [[methane]] in their atmospheres, appearing like Jovian-mass versions of [[Uranus]] and [[Neptune]]. Because of the lack of a reflective cloud layer, the Bond albedo is low, around 0.12 for a class-III planet around a Sun-like star. They exist in the inner regions of a planetary system, roughly corresponding to the location of [[Mercury (planet)|Mercury]].
Possible class-III planets are [[HD 37124 b]], [[HD 18742 b]], [[HD 178911 Bb]], [[55 Cancri c]], [[Upsilon Andromedae c]], [[Kepler-89e]], [[COROT-9b]] and [[HD 205739 b]]. Above 700 K (800 °F, 430 °C), sulfides and chlorides might provide [[cirrus cloud|cirrus]]-like clouds.<ref name="sudarsky2" />
=== Class IV: Alkali metals === Above 900 K (630 °C/1160 °F), [[carbon monoxide]] becomes the dominant carbon-carrying molecule in a gas giant's atmosphere (rather than [[methane]]). Furthermore, the abundance of [[alkali metal]]s, such as [[sodium]] substantially increase, and [[spectral line]]s of [[sodium]] and [[potassium]] are predicted to be prominent in a gas giant's [[spectrum]]. These planets form cloud decks of [[silicate]]s and [[iron]] deep in their atmospheres, but this is not predicted to affect their spectrum. The Bond albedo of a class IV planet around a Sun-like star is predicted to be very low, at 0.03 because of the strong absorption by alkali metals. Gas giants of classes IV and V are referred to as [[hot Jupiter]]s.
[[55 Cancri b]] was listed as a class IV planet.<ref name="sudarsky2"/>
[[HD 209458 b]] at 1300 K (1000 °C) would be another such planet, with a geometric albedo of, within error limits, zero; and in 2001, NASA witnessed atmospheric sodium in its transit, though less than predicted. This planet hosts an upper cloud deck absorbing so much heat that below it is a relatively cool [[stratosphere]]. The composition of this dark cloud, in the models, is assumed to be titanium/vanadium oxide (sometimes abbreviated "TiVO"), by analogy with red dwarfs, but its true composition is yet unknown; it could well be as per Sudarsky.<ref name=hubeny>{{Cite journal |title=Spectrum and atmosphere models of irradiated transiting extrasolar giant planets |arxiv=0807.3588|date=2008 |author1=Ivan Hubeny |author2=Adam Burrows |doi=10.1017/S1743921308026458 |volume=4 |journal=Proceedings of the International Astronomical Union |page=239|bibcode=2009IAUS..253..239H}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |title=Radiative Hydrodynamical Studies of Irradiated Atmospheres |arxiv=0807.4541 |date=2008 |author1=Ian Dobbs-Dixon |doi=10.1017/S1743921308026495 |volume=4 |journal=Proceedings of the International Astronomical Union |page=273|bibcode=2009IAUS..253..273D }}</ref>
[[HD 189733 b]], with measured temperatures 920–1200 K (650–930 °C), also qualifies as class IV. However, in late 2007 it was measured as deep blue, with an albedo over 0.14 (possibly due to the brighter glow of its "hot spot"). No stratosphere has been conclusively proven for it as yet.
[[TrES-2b]] was measured with the lowest albedo, and therefore listed as class IV.
=== Class V: Silicate clouds === For the very hottest gas giants, with temperatures above 1400 K (2100 °F, 1100 °C) or cooler planets with lower gravity than Jupiter, the [[silicate]] and [[iron]] cloud decks are predicted to lie high up in the atmosphere. The predicted Bond albedo of a class V planet around a Sun-like star is 0.55, due to reflection by the cloud decks. At such temperatures, a gas giant may glow red from thermal radiation but the reflected light generally overwhelms thermal radiation. For stars of visual apparent magnitude under 4.50, such planets are theoretically visible to our instruments.<ref>{{cite journal | author1 = Leigh C. | author2 = Collier C. A. | author3 = Horne K. | author4 = Penny A. | author5 = James D. | year = 2003 | title = A new upper limit on the reflected starlight from Tau Bootis b. | url = | journal = MNRAS | volume = 344 | issue = 4| page = 1271 | doi=10.1046/j.1365-8711.2003.06901.x|arxiv = astro-ph/0308413 |bibcode = 2003MNRAS.344.1271L }}</ref> Examples of such planets might include [[51 Pegasi b]] and [[Upsilon Andromedae b]].<ref name="sudarsky2" /> [[HAT-P-11b]] and those other extrasolar gas giants found by the [[Kepler telescope]] might be possible class V planets, such as [[Kepler-7b]], [[HAT-P-7b]], or [[Kepler-13 b]].

{{Distinguish|Taylor Law|Taylor rule}} '''Taylor's law''' (also known as '''Taylor's power law''') is an empirical law in [[ecology]] that relates the [[variance]] of the [[population density|number of individuals of a species per unit area]] of habitat to the corresponding [[mean]] by a [[power law]] relationship.<ref name=Taylor1961>{{cite journal|last1=Taylor|first1=L. R. |year=1961 |title=Aggregation, variance and the mean |journal=Nature |volume=189 |issue=4766 |pages=732–735 |doi=10.1038/189732a0}}</ref> It is named after the ecologist who first proposed it in 1961, [[Roy Taylor (ecologist)|Lionel Roy Taylor]] (1924–2007).<ref name=Southwood1966>{{cite book|author1=Thomas R. E. Southwood |title=Ecological methods, with particular reference to the study of insect populations|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=StwPAQAAMAAJ |year=1966 |publisher=Methuen}}</ref> Taylor's original name for this relationship was the law of the mean.<ref name=Taylor1961/>
==Definition== This law was originally defined for ecological systems, specifically to assess the spatial clustering of organisms. For a population count ''Y'' with mean ''µ'' and variance var(''Y''), Taylor's law is written,
: <math>\operatorname{var} (Y) = a\mu^b,</math>
where ''a'' and ''b'' are both positive constants. Taylor proposed this relationship in 1961, suggesting that the exponent ''b'' be considered a species specific index of aggregation.<ref name="Taylor1961"/> This power law has subsequently been confirmed for many hundreds of species.<ref name=Taylor1980>{{cite journal|last1=Taylor|first1=L. R.|last2=Woiwod|first2=I. P. |year=1980 |title=Temporal stability as a density-dependent species characteristic |journal=Journal of Animal Ecology |volume=49 |issue=1 |pages=209–224 |doi=10.2307/4285 |jstor=4285}}</ref><ref name=Taylor1982>Taylor LR & Woiwod (1982) Comparative Synoptic Dynamics. I. Relationships Between Inter- and Intra-Specific Spatial and Temporal Variance/Mean Population Parameters. ''J Animal Ecol'' 51, 879–906</ref>
Taylor's law has also been applied to assess the time dependent changes of population distributions.<ref name=Taylor1980 /> Related variance to mean power laws have also been demonstrated in several non-ecological systems: *cancer metastasis<ref name=Kendal1987>Kendal WS & Frost P (1987) Experimental metastasis: a novel application of the variance-to-mean power function. ''J Natl Cancer Inst'' 79, 1113–1115</ref> *the numbers of houses built over the Tonami plain in Japan.<ref name=Kendal1995>Kendal WS (1995) A probabilistic model for the variance to mean power law in ecology. Ecological Modelling 80, 293–297</ref> *measles epidemiology<ref name=Keeling1999>Keeling M & Grenfell B (1999) Stochastic dynamics and a power law for measles variability. ''Phil Trans R Soc Lond B Biol Sci'' 354, 769–776</ref> *[[HIV]] epidemiology,<ref name=Anderson1989>Anderson RM & May RM (1989) Epidemiological parameters of HIV transmission. ''Nature'' 333, 514–519</ref> *the geographic clustering of childhood [[leukemia]]<ref name=Philippe1999>Philippe P (1999) The scale-invariant spatial clustering of leukemia in San Francisco. ''J Theor Biol'' 199, 371-381</ref> *blood flow heterogeneity<ref name=Bassingthwaighte1989>Bassingthwaighte JB (1989) Fractal nature of regional myocardial blood flow heterogeneity. ''Circ Res'' 65, 578–590</ref><ref name=Kendal2001>Kendal WS (2001) A stochastic model for the self-similar heterogeneity of regional organ blood flow. ''Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A'' 98, 837–841</ref> *the genomic distributions of [[single-nucleotide polymorphism]]s (SNPs)<ref name=Kendal2003>Kendal WS (2003) An exponential dispersion model for the distribution of human single nucleotide polymorphisms. Mol Biol Evol 20 579–590</ref> *gene structures<ref name=Kendal2004>Kendal WS (2004) A scale invariant clustering of genes on human chromosome 7. ''BMC Evol Biol'' 4(1), 3</ref> *in [[number theory]] with sequential values of the [[Mertens function]]<ref name=Kendal2011a>Kendal WS & Jørgensen B (2011) Taylor's power law and fluctuation scaling explained by a central-limit-like convergence. ''Phys. Rev. E'' 83,066115</ref> and also with the distribution of [[prime number]]s <ref>{{cite journal|last=Kendal|first=W|title=Fluctuation scaling and 1/f noise: shared origins from the Tweedie family of statistical distributions|journal=J Basic Appl Phys|year=2013|volume=2|issue=2|pages=40–9}}</ref><ref name=Kendal2015a>Kendal WS & Jørgensen B (2015) A scale invariant distribution of the prime numbers. ''Computation'' 2015, 3, 528–540</ref> *from the eigenvalue deviations of Gaussian orthogonal and unitary ensembles of [[random matrix]] theory<ref name=Kendal2011b>Kendal WS & Jørgensen BR (2011) Tweedie convergence: a mathematical basis for Taylor's power law, 1/''f'' noise and multifractality. ''Phys. Rev. E'' 84, 066120</ref>
==History==
The first use of a double log-log plot was by [[Osborne Reynolds|Reynolds]] in 1879 on thermal aerodynamics.<ref name=Reynolds1879>Reynolds O (1879) On certain dimensional properties of matter in the gaseous state. Part I. Experimental researches on thermal transpiration of gases through porous plates and on the laws of transpiration and impulsion, including an experimental proof that gas is not a continuous plenum. Part II. On an extension of the dynamical theory of gas, which includes the stresses, tangential and normal, caused by a varying condition of gas, and affords an explanation of the phenomena of transpiration and impulsion. Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London 170:727-845</ref> [[Vilfredo Pareto|Pareto]] used a similar plot to study the proportion of a population and their income.<ref name=Pareto1897>Pareto V (1897) Cours D'économie Politique. Volume 2. Lausanne: F. Rouge</ref>
The term ''[[variance]]'' was coined by [[Ronald Fisher|Fisher]] in 1918.<ref name=Fisher1918>{{cite journal | last=Fisher | first=RA | title=The correlation between relatives on the supposition of Mendelian inheritance | journal=Transactions of the Royal Society of Edinburgh | year=1918 | volume=52 | pages=399–433 | doi=10.1017/S0080456800012163 | issue=2}}</ref>
===Biology===
Fisher<ref name=Fisher1921>Fisher RA (1921) Studies in crop variation. I. An examination of the yield of dressed grain from Broadbalk. Journal of Agricultural Science 11:107–135</ref> in 1921 proposed the equation
: <math> s^2 = a m + b m^2 </math>
[[Jerzy Neyman|Neyman]] studied the relationship between the sample mean and variance in 1926.<ref name=Neyman1926>Neyman J (1926) On the correlation of the mean and the variance in samples drawn from an "infinite" population. Biometrika 18:401–413</ref> [[M. S. Bartlett|Barlett]] proposed a relationship between the sample mean and variance in 1936<ref name=Bartlett1936>Bartlett M (1936) Some notes on insecticide tests in the laboratory and in the field. J Roy Stat Soc Supplement 3: 185–194</ref>
: <math> s^2 = a m + b m^2 </math>
Smith in 1938 while studying crop yields proposed a relationship similar to Taylor's.<ref name=Smith1938>Smith HF (1938) An empirical law describing heterogeneity in the yield of agricultural crops. J Agric Sci 28: 1-23</ref> This relationship was
: <math> \log V_x = \log V_1 + b\log x \, </math>
where ''V''<sub>''x''</sub> is the variance of yield for plots of ''x'' units, ''V''<sub>1</sub> is the variance of yield per unit area and ''x'' is the size of plots. The slope (''b'') is the index of heterogeneity. The value of ''b'' in this relationship lies between 0 and 1. Where the yield are highly correlated ''b'' tends to 0; when they are uncorrelated ''b'' tends to 1.
Bliss<ref name=Bliss1941>Bliss CI (1941) Statistical problems in estimating populations of Japanese beetle larve. ''J Econ Entomol'' 34, 221-232</ref> in 1941, Fracker and Brischle<ref name=Fracker1944>Fracker SB & Brischle HA (1944) Measuring the local distribution of ''Ribes''. Ecology 25: 283–303</ref> in 1941 and Hayman & Lowe <ref name=Hayman1961>Hayman BI & Lowe AD (1961) The transformation of counts of the cabbage aphid (''Brevicovyne brassicae'' (L.)) NZ J Sci 4:271–278</ref> in 1961 also described what is now known as Taylor's law, but in the context of data from single species.
L. R. Taylor (1924–2007) was an English entomologist who worked on the Rothamsted Insect Survey for pest control. His 1961 paper used data from 24 papers published between 1936 and 1960. These papers considered a variety of biological settings: [[virus]] lesions, [[zooplankton|macro-zooplankton]], [[worm]]s and [[symphylid]]s in [[soil]], [[insect]]s in soil, on [[plant]]s and in the air, [[mite]]s on [[leaf|leaves]], [[tick]]s on [[sheep]] and [[fish]] in the [[sea]].<ref name="Taylor1961"/> In these papers the ''b'' value lay between 1 and 3. Taylor proposed the power law as a general feature of the spatial distribution of these species. He also proposed a mechanistic hypothesis to explain this law. Among the papers cited were those of Bliss and Yates and Finney.
Initial attempts to explain the spatial distribution of animals had been based on approaches like [[M. S. Bartlet|Bartlett's]] stochastic population models and the [[negative binomial distribution]] that could result from [[birth-death process]]es.<ref name=Taylor1984>Taylor LR (1984) Anscombe’s hypothesis and the changing distributions of insect populations. ''Antenna'' 8, 62–67</ref> Taylor's novel explanation was based the assumption of a balanced migratory and congregatory behavior of animals.<ref name="Taylor1961"/> His hypothesis was initially qualitative, but as it evolved it became semi-quantitative and was supported by simulations.<ref name=Taylor1977>Taylor LR & Taylor RAJ (1977) Aggregation, migration and population mechanics. ''Nature'' 265, 415–421</ref> In proposing that animal behavior was the principal mechanism behind the clustering of organisms, Taylor though appeared to have ignored his own report of clustering seen with tobacco necrosis virus plaques.<ref name="Taylor1961"/>
Following Taylor's initial publications several alternative hypotheses for the power law were advanced. Hanski proposed a random walk model, modulated by the presumed multiplicative effect of reproduction.<ref name=Hanski1980>Hanski I (1980) Spatial patterns and movements in coprophagous beetles. ''Oikos'' 34, 293–310</ref> Hanski's model predicted that the power law exponent would be constrained to range closely about the value of 2, which seemed inconsistent with many reported values.<ref name=Taylor1980 /><ref name="Taylor1982"/>
Anderson ''et al'' formulated a simple stochastic birth, death, immigration and emigration model that yielded a quadratic variance function.<ref name=Anderson1961>Anderson RD, Crawley GM & Hassell M (1982) Variability in the abundance of animal and plant species. ''Nature'' 296, 245–248</ref> As a response to this model Taylor argued that such a [[Markov process]] would predict that the power law exponent would vary considerably between replicate observations, and that such variability had not been observed.<ref name=Taylor1983>Taylor LR, Taylor RAJ, Woiwod IP & Perry JN (1983) Behavioural dynamics. ''Nature'' 303, 801–804</ref>
About this time concerns were, however, raised regarding the statistical variability with measurements of the power law exponent, and the possibility that observations of a power law might reflect more mathematical artifact than a mechanistic process.<ref name=Downing1986>Downing JA (1986) Spatial heterogeneity: evolved behaviour or mathematical artefact? ''Nature'' 323, 255–257</ref> Taylor ''et al'' responded with an additional publication of extensive observations which he claimed refuted Downing's concerns.<ref name=Taylor1988>Taylor LR (1988) Specificity of the spatial power-law exponent in ecology and agriculture. ''Nature'' 332, 721–722</ref>
In addition, Thórarinsson published a detailed critique of the animal behavioral model, noting that Taylor had modified his model several times in response to concerns raised, and that some of these modifications were inconsistent with earlier versions.<ref name="Thórarinsson1986"> Thórarinsson K (1986) Population density and movement: a critique of Δ-models. ''Oikos'' 189, 70–81</ref> Thórarinsson also claimed that Taylor confounded animal numbers with density and that Taylor had incorrectly interpreted simulations that had been constructed to demonstrate his models as validation.
Kemp reviewed a number of discrete stochastic models based on the negative binomial, Neyman type A, and Polya–Aeppli distributions that with suitable adjustment of parameters could produce a variance to mean power law.<ref name=Kemp1987>Kemp AW (1987) Families of discrete distributions satisfying Taylor’s power law. ''Biometrics'' 43, 693–699</ref> Kemp, however, did not explain the parameterizations of his models in mechanistic terms. Other relatively abstract models for Taylor's law followed.<ref name="Kendal1995"/><ref name=Yamamura1990>Yamamura K (1990) Sampling scale dependence of Taylor’s power law. ''Oikos'' 59, 121–125</ref>
A number of additional statistical concerns were raised regarding Taylor's law, based on the difficulty with real data in distinguishing between Taylor's law and other variance to mean functions, as well the inaccuracy of standard regression methods.<ref name=Routledge1991>Routledge RD & Swartz TB (1991) Taylor’s power law re-examined. ''Oikos'' 60, 107–112</ref><ref name=Tokeshi1995>Tokeshi M (1995) On the mathematical basis of the variance–mean power relationship. ''Res Pop Ecol'' 37, 43–48</ref>
Reports also began to accumulate where Taylor's law had been applied to time series data. Perry showed how simulations based on [[chaos theory]] could yield Taylor's law, and Kilpatrick & Ives provided simulations which showed how interactions between different species might lead to Taylor's law.<ref name=Perry1994>Perry JN (1994) Chaotic dynamics can generate Taylor’s power law. ''Proc Roy Soc Lond Ser B Biol Sci'' 257, 221–226</ref><ref name=Kilpatrick2003>Kilpatrick AM & Ives AR (2003) Species interactions can explain Taylor’s power law for ecological time series. ''Nature'' 422, 65–68</ref>
Other reports appeared where Taylor's law had been applied to the spatial distribution of plants<ref name=Clark1996>Clark S, Perry JJN & Marshall JP (1996) Estimating Taylor’s power law parameters for weeds and the effect of spatial scale. ''Weed Res'' 36, 405–417</ref> and bacterial populations<ref name=Ramsayer2011>Ramsayer J, Fellous S, Cohen JE & Hochberg ME (2011) Taylor's Law holds in experimental bacterial populations but competition does not influence the slope. ''Biology Letters''</ref> As with the observations of Tobacco necrosis virus mentioned earlier, these observations were not consistent with Taylor's animal behavioral model.
Earlier it was mentioned that variance to mean power function had been applied to non-ecological systems, under the rubric of Taylor's law. To provide a more general explanation for the range of manifestations of the power law a hypothesis was proposed based on the [[Tweedie distributions]],<ref name="Jørgensen-1997">{{cite book | author = Jørgensen, Bent | year = 1997| title = The theory of dispersion models | publisher = [Chapman & Hall] | isbn = 978-0412997112 }}</ref> a family of probabilistic models that express an inherent power function relationship between the variance and the mean.<ref name=Kendal2001 /><ref name=Kendal2004 /><ref name=Kendal2002>Kendal WS (2002) Spatial aggregation of the Colorado potato beetle described by an exponential dispersion model. ''Ecol Model'' 151, 261–269</ref> Details regarding this hypothesis will be provided in the next section.
A further alternative explanation for Taylor's law was proposed by [[Joel E. Cohen|Cohen]] ''et al'', derived from the [[Richard Lewontin|Lewontin]] Cohen [[Population dynamics|growth model]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Cohen|first=J E |author2=Xu, m |author3=Schuster, W S|title=Stochastic multiplicative population growth predicts and interprets Taylor's power law of fluctuation scaling|journal=Proc R Soc Lond B Biol Sci|year=2013|volume=280|page=20122955}}</ref> This model was successfully used to describe the spatial and temporal variability of forest populations.
Another paper by Cohen and Xu that random sampling in blocks where the underling distribution is skewed with the first four moments finite gives rise to Taylor's law.<ref name=Cohen2015>Cohen JE, Xu M (2015) Random sampling of skewed distributions implies Taylor's power law of fluctuation scaling. Proc Natl Acad Sci USA 112(25):7749–7754. doi: 10.1073/pnas.1503824112</ref> Approximate formulae for the parameters and their variances were also derived. These estimates were tested again data from the Black Rock Forest and found to be in reasonable agreement.
Following Taylor's initial publications several alternative hypotheses for the power law were advanced. Hanski proposed a random walk model, modulated by the presumed multiplicative effect of reproduction.<ref name=Hanski1980>Hanski I (1980) Spatial patterns and movements in coprophagous beetles. ''Oikos'' 34, 293–310</ref> Hanski's model predicted that the power law exponent would be constrained to range closely about the value of 2, which seemed inconsistent with many reported values.<ref name=Taylor1980 /><ref name="Taylor1982"/> Anderson ''et al'' formulated a simple stochastic birth, death, immigration and emigration model that yielded a quadratic variance function.<ref name=Anderson1961>Anderson RD, Crawley GM & Hassell M (1982) Variability in the abundance of animal and plant species. ''Nature'' 296, 245–248</ref> The [[Richard Lewontin|Lewontin]] Cohen [[Population dynamics|growth model]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Cohen|first=J E |author2=Xu, m |author3=Schuster, W S|title=Stochastic multiplicative population growth predicts and interprets Taylor's power law of fluctuation scaling|journal=Proc R Soc Lond B Biol Sci|year=2013|volume=280|page=20122955}}</ref> is another proposed explanation. The possibility that observations of a power law might reflect more mathematical artifact than a mechanistic process was raised.<ref name=Downing1986>Downing JA (1986) Spatial heterogeneity: evolved behaviour or mathematical artefact? ''Nature'' 323, 255–257</ref>
===Physics===
In the physics literature Taylor's law has been referred to as ''fluctuation scaling''. Eisler ''et al'', in a further attempt to find a general explanation for fluctuation scaling, proposed a process they called ''impact inhomogeneity'' in which frequent events are associated with larger impacts.<ref name=Eisler2008>Eisler Z, Bartos I & Kertesz (2008) Fluctuation scaling in complex systems: Taylor’s law and beyond. ''Adv Phys'' 57, 89–142</ref> In appendix B of the Eisler article, however, the authors noted that the equations for impact inhomogeneity yielded the same mathematical relationships as found with the Tweedie distributions.
Another group of physicists, Fronczak and Fronczak, derived Taylor's power law for fluctuation scaling from principles of equilibrium and non-equilibrium [[statistical physics]].<ref name=Fronczak2010>Fronczak A & Fronczak P (2010) Origins of Taylor’s power law for fluctuation scaling in complex systems. ''Phys Rev E'' 81, 066112</ref> Their derivation was based on assumptions of physical quantities like [[Thermodynamic free energy|free energy]] and an external [[field (physics)|field]] that caused the clustering of biological organisms. Direct experimental demonstration of these postulated physical quantities in relationship to animal or plant aggregation has yet to be achieved, though. Shortly thereafter, an analysis of Fronczak and Fronczak's model was presented that showed their equations directly lead to the Tweedie distributions, a finding that suggested that Fronczak and Fronczak had possibly provided a [[maximum entropy probability distribution|maximum entropy]] derivation of these distributions.<ref name="Kendal2011a"/>
===Mathematics===
Taylor's law has been shown to hold for [[prime number]]s not exceeding a given real number.<ref name=Cohen2016>Cohen JE (2016) Statistics of primes (and probably twin primes) satisfy Taylor's Law from ecology. The American Statistician 70 (4) 399–404</ref> This result has been shown to hold for the first 11 million primes. If the [[Twin prime|Hardy–Littlewood twin primes conjecture]] is true then this law also holds for twin primes.
===Naming of law===
The law itself is named after the ecologist [[Roy Taylor (ecologist)|Lionel Roy Taylor]] (1924–2007). The name 'Taylor's law' was coined by Southwood in 1966.<ref name=Southwood1966/> Taylor's original name for this relationship was the law of the mean
==The Tweedie Hypothesis==
About the time that Taylor was substantiating his ecological observations, [[Maurice Tweedie|MCK Tweedie]], a British statistician and medical physicist, was investigating a family of probabilistic models that are now known as the [[Tweedie distributions]].<ref name=Tweedie1984>Tweedie MCK (1984) An index which distinguishes between some important exponential families. In: ''Statistics: Applications and New Directions Proceedings of the Indian Statistical Institute Golden Jubilee International Conference'' pp 579-604 Eds: JK Ghosh & J Roy, Indian Statistical Institute, Calcutta</ref><ref name="Jørgensen1987">Jørgensen B (1987)Exponential dispersion models. ''J Roy Stat Soc Ser B'' 49, 127–162}</ref> As mentioned above, these distributions are all characterized by a variance to mean power law mathematically identical to Taylor's law.
The Tweedie distribution most applicable to ecological observations is the [[compound Poisson distribution|compound Poisson-gamma distribution]], which represents the sum of ''N'' independent and identically distributed random variables with a gamma distribution where ''N'' is a random variable distributed in accordance with a Poisson distribution. In the additive form its [[cumulant|cumulant generating function]] (CGF) is:
: <math>K^*_b(s;\theta,\lambda)=\lambda\kappa_b(\theta)\left [\left(1+{s \over \theta}\right)^\alpha-1\right]</math>,
where ''κ''<sub>''b''</sub>(''θ'') is the cumulant function,
: <math>\kappa_b(\theta)={(\alpha-1)\over \alpha}\left({\theta \over (\alpha-1)}\right)^\alpha</math>,
the Tweedie exponent
: <math>\alpha=(b-2)/(b-1)</math>,
''s'' is the generating function variable, and ''θ'' and ''λ'' are the canonical and index parameters, respectively.<ref name="Jørgensen-1997"/>
These last two parameters are analogous to the [[scale parameter|scale]] and [[shape parameter]]s used in probability theory. The [[cumulant]]s of this distribution can be determined by successive differentiations of the CGF and then substituting ''s=0'' into the resultant equations. The first and second cumulants are the mean and variance, respectively, and thus the compound Poisson-gamma CGF yields Taylor's law with the proportionality constant
: <math>a=\lambda^{1/(\alpha-1)}</math>.
The compound Poisson-gamma cumulative distribution function has been verified for limited ecological data through the comparison of the theoretical distribution function with the empirical distribution function.<ref name=Kendal2002 /> A number of other systems, demonstrating variance to mean power laws related to Taylor's law, have been similarly tested for the compound Poisson-gamma distribution.<ref name=Kendal2003 /><ref name=Kendal2004 /><ref name="Kendal2011a"/><ref name="Kendal2011b"/>
The main justification for the Tweedie hypothesis rests with the mathematical [[convergence (mathematics)|convergence]] properties of the Tweedie distributions.<ref name=Kendal2004 /> The [[Tweedie distributions|'''Tweedie convergence theorem''']] requires the Tweedie distributions to act as foci of convergence for a wide range of statistical processes.<ref name="Jørgensen1994">Jørgensen B, Marinez JR & Tsao M (1994) Asymptotic behaviour of the variance function. ''Scandinavian Journal of Statistics'' 21, 223–243</ref> As a consequence of this convergence theorem, processes based on the sum of multiple independent small jumps will tend to express Taylor's law and obey a Tweedie distribution. A limit theorem for independent and identically distributed variables, as with the Tweedie convergence theorem, might then be considered as being fundamental relative to the ''ad hoc'' population models, or models proposed on the basis of simulation or approximation.<ref name="Kendal2011a"/><ref name="Kendal2011b"/>
This hypothesis remains controversial; more conventional [[Population dynamics|population dynamic]] approaches seem preferred amongst ecologists, despite the fact that the Tweedie compound Poisson distribution can be directly applied to population dynamic mechanisms.<ref name=Kendal1995/>
One difficulty with the Tweedie hypothesis is that the value of ''b'' does not range between 0 and 1. Values of ''b'' < 1 are rare but have been reported.<ref name=Wilson1982>Wilson LT & Room PM (1982) The relative efficiency and reliability of three methods for sampling arthropods in Australian cotton fields. J Aust Entomol Soc 21: 175-181</ref>
==Mathematical formulation==
In symbols
: <math> s_i^2 = am_i^b </math>,
where ''s''<sub>''i''</sub><sup>2</sup> is the [[variance]] of the density of the ''i''th sample, ''m''<sub>''i''</sub> is the [[mean]] density of the ''i''th sample and ''a'' and ''b'' are constants.
In logarithmic form
: <math> \log s_i^2 = \log a + b\log m_i </math>
===Scale invariance===
Taylor's law is scale invariant. If the unit of measurement is changed by a constant factor ''c'', the exponent (''b'') remains unchanged.
To see this let ''y'' = ''cx''. Then
<math> \mu_1 = \mathbb{E}( x ) </math>
<math> \mu_2 = \mathbb{E}( y ) =\mathbb{E}( c\,x ) = c \, \mathbb{E}( x ) = c\, \mu_1</math>
<math> \sigma^2_1 = \mathbb{E} ( x - \mu_1 )^2 </math>
<math> \sigma^2_2 = \mathbb{E}( y - \mu_2 )^2 = \mathbb{E}( c\,x - c\, \mu_1 )^2 = c^2 \mathbb{E} ( x - \mu_1 )^2 = c^2\, \sigma^2_1 </math>
Taylor's law expressed in the original variable (''x'') is
<math> \sigma_1^2 = a \mu_1^b </math>
and in the rescaled variable (''y'') it is
<math> \sigma_2^2 = a \mu_2^b = c^2 \sigma_1^2 = c^2 a \mu_1^b </math>
It has been shown that Taylor's law is the only relationship between the mean and variance that is scale invariant.<ref name="Jørgensen1997">Jørgensen B (1997) The theory of exponential dispersion models. Chapman & Hall. London</ref>
===Extensions and refinements===
A refinement in the estimation of the slope ''b'' has been proposed by Rayner.<ref name=Rayner1985>Rayner JMV (1985) Linear relations in biomechanics: the statistics of scaling functions. J Zoo 206 (3) 415–439</ref>
: <math> b = \frac { f - \varphi + \sqrt{ ( f - \varphi )^2 - 4 r^2 f \varphi } }{ 2 r \sqrt{ f } } </math>
where ''r'' is the [[Pearson product-moment correlation coefficient|Pearson moment correlation coefficient]] between log(''s''<sup>2</sup>) and log ''m'', ''f'' is the ratio of sample variances in log(''s''<sup>2</sup>) and log ''m'' and ''φ'' is the ratio of the errors in log(''s''<sup>2</sup>) and log ''m''.
Ordinary least squares regression assumes that ''φ'' = ∞. This tends to underestimate the value of ''b'' because the estimates of both log(''s''<sup>2</sup>) and log ''m'' are subject to error.
An extension of Taylor's law has been proposed by Ferris ''et al'' when multiple samples are taken<ref name=Ferris1990>Ferris H, Mullens TA, Foord KE (1990) Stability and characteristics of spatial description parameters for nematode populations. J Nematol 22(4):427-439</ref>
: <math> s^2 = ( c n^d ) ( m^b ) </math>,
where ''s''<sup>2</sup> and ''m'' are the variance and mean respectively, ''b'', ''c'' and ''d'' are constants and ''n'' is the number of samples taken. To date, this proposed extension has not been verified to be as applicable as the original version of Taylor's law.
===Small samples===
An extension to this law for small samples has been proposed by Hanski.<ref name=Hanski1982>Hanski I(1982) On patterns of temporal and spatial variation in animal populations. Ann. zool. Fermici 19: 21—37</ref> For small samples the Poisson variation (''P'') - the variation that can be ascribed to sampling variation - may be significant. Let ''S'' be the total variance and let ''V'' be the biological (real) variance. Then
: <math> S = V + P </math>
Assuming the validity of Taylor's law, we have
: <math> V = a m^b </math>
Because in the Poisson distribution the mean equals the variance, we have
: <math> P = m </math>
This gives us
: <math> S = V + P = a m^b + m </math>
This closely resembles Barlett's original suggestion.
===Interpretation===
Slope values (''b'') significantly > 1 indicate clumping of the organisms.
In [[Poisson distribution|Poisson-distributed]] data, ''b'' = 1.<ref name=Taylor1983/> If the population follows a [[lognormal distribution|lognormal]] or [[gamma distribution]], then ''b'' = 2.
For populations that are experiencing constant per capita environmental variability, the regression of log( variance ) versus log( mean abundance ) should have a line with ''b'' = 2.
Most populations that have been studied have ''b'' < 2 (usually 1.5–1.6) but values of 2 have been reported.<ref name=Boag1992>Boag B, Hackett CA, Topham PB (1992) The use of Taylor's power law to describe the aggregated distribution of gastro-intestinal nematodes of sheep. Int J Parasitol 22(3):267–270</ref> Occasionally cases with ''b'' > 2 have been reported.<ref name=Taylor1980 /> ''b'' values below 1 are uncommon but have also been reported ( ''b'' = 0.93 ).<ref name="Wilson1982"/>
It has been suggested that the exponent of the law (''b'') is proportional to the skewness of the underlying distribution.<ref name=v2015>Cohen J E, Xua M (2015) Random sampling of skewed distributions implies Taylor’s power law of fluctuation scaling.Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA 2015 112 (25) 7749–7754</ref> This proposal has criticised: additional work seems to be indicated.<ref name=Anon2015a>Reply to Chen: Under specified assumptions, adequate random samples of skewed distributions obey Taylor's law (2015) Proc Natl Acad Sci USA 112 (25) E3157-E3158</ref><ref name=Anon2015b>Random sampling of skewed distributions does not necessarily imply Taylor's law (2015) Proc Natl Acad Sci USA 112 (25) E3156</ref>
===Notes===
The origin of the slope (''b'') in this regression remains unclear. Two hypotheses have been proposed to explain it. One suggests that ''b'' arises from the species behavior and is a constant for that species. The alternative suggests that it is dependent on the sampled population. Despite the considerable number of studies carried out on this law (over 1000), this question remains open.
It is known that both ''a'' and ''b'' are subject to change due to age-specific dispersal, mortality and sample unit size.<ref name=Banerjee1976>Banerjee B (1976) Variance to mean ratio and the spatial distribution of animals. Experientia 32: 993-994</ref>
This law may be a poor fit if the values are small. For this reason an extension to Taylor's law has been proposed by [[Ilkka Hanski|Hanski]] which improves the fit of Taylor's law at low densities.<ref name=Hanski1982 />
===Extension to cluster sampling of binary data===
A form of Taylor's law applicable to binary data in clusters (e.q., quadrats) has been proposed.<ref name=Hughes&Madden1992>Hughes G, and Madden LV (1992) Aggregation and incidence of disease. Plant Pathology 41(6):657–660</ref> In a binomial distribution, the theoretical variance is
: <math> var_{ bin } = n p ( 1 - p ) </math>,
where ''(var<sub>bin</sub>)'' is the binomial variance, ''n'' is the sample size per cluster, and ''p'' is the proportion of individuals with a trait (such as disease), an estimate of the probability of an individual having that trait.
One difficulty with binary data is that the mean and variance, in general, have a particular relationship: as the mean proportion of individuals infected increases above 0.5, the variance deceases.
It is now known that the observed variance ''(var<sub>obs</sub>)'' changes as a power function of ''(var<sub>bin</sub>)''.<ref name="Hughes&Madden1992"/>
Hughes and Madden noted that if the distribution is Poisson, the mean and variance are equal.<ref name="Hughes&Madden1992"/> As this is clearly not the case in many observed proportion samples, they instead assumed a binomial distribution. They replaced the mean in Taylor's law with the binomial variance and then compared this theoretical variance with the observed variance. For binomial data, they showed that ''var<sub>obs</sub> = var<sub>bin</sub>'' with overdispersion, ''var<sub>obs</sub>'' > ''var<sub>bin</sub>''.
In symbols, Hughes and Madden's modification to Tyalor's law was
: <math> var_{ obs } = a( var_{ bin } )^b </math>.
In logarithmic form this relationship is
: <math> \log( var_{ obs } ) = \log( a ) + b \log( var_{ bin } ) </math>.
This latter version is known as the binary power law.
A key step in the derivation of the binary power law by Hughes and Madden was the observation made by Patil and Stiteler<ref name=Patil&Stiteler1974>Patil GP, and Stiteler WM (1974) Concepts of aggregation and their quantification: a critical review with some new results and applications. Researches on Population Ecology 15:238-254</ref> that the variance-to-mean ratio used for assessing over-dispersion of unbounded counts in a single sample is actually the ratio of two variances: the observed variance and the theoretical variance for a random distribution. For unbounded counts, the random distribution is the Poisson. Thus, the Taylor power law for a collection of samples can be considered as a relationship between the observed variance and the Poisson variance.
More broadly, Madden and Hughes<ref name="Hughes&Madden1992"/> considered the power law as the relationship between two variances, the observed variance and the theoretical variance for a random distribution. With binary data, the random distribution is the binomial (not the Poisson). Thus the Taylor power law and the binary power law are two special cases of a general power-law relationships for heterogeneity.
When both ''a'' and ''b'' are equal to 1, then a small-scale random spatial pattern is suggested and is best described by the binomial distribution. When ''b'' = 1 and ''a'' > 1, there is over-dispersion (small scale aggregation). When ''b'' is > 1, the degree of aggregation varies with ''p''. Turechek ''et al''<ref name="Turechek et al.2011">Turechek WW, Madden LV, Gent DH, Xu XM (2011) Comments regarding the binary power law for heterogeneity of disease incidence. Phytopathology 101(12):1396-1407</ref> have showed that the binary power law describes numerous data sets in plant pathology. In general, ''b'' is greater than 1 and less than 2.
The fit of this law has been tested by simulations.<ref name=Gosme2009>{{cite journal|first1=Marie|last1=Gosme|first2=Philippe|last2=Lucas|title=Disease Spread Across Multiple Scales in a Spatial Hierarchy: Effect of Host Spatial Structure and of Inoculum Quantity and Distribution|url=http://apsjournals.apsnet.org/doi/pdf/10.1094/PHYTO-99-7-0833|journal=Phytopathology|date=2009-06-12|issn=0031-949X|pages=833–839|volume=99|issue=7|doi=10.1094/phyto-99-7-0833|doi-access=free}}</ref> These results suggest that rather than a single regression line for the data set, a segmental regression may be a better model for genuinely random distributions. However, this segmentation only occurs for very short-range dispersal distances and large quadrat sizes.<ref name="Turechek et al.2011"/> The break in the line occurs only at ''p'' very close to 0.
An extension to this law has been proposed.<ref name=Xu2014>Xu X-M, Madden LV (2013) The limits of the binary power law describing spatial variability for incidence data. Plant Pathology 63 (5) 973–982</ref> The original form of this law is symmetrical but it can be extended to an asymmetrical form.<ref name="Xu2014"/> Using simulations the symmetrical form fits the data when there is positive correlation of disease status of neighbors. Where there is a negative correlation between the likelihood of neighbours being infected, the asymmetrical version is a better fit to the data.
==Applications==
Because of the ubiquitous occurrence of Taylor's law in biology it has found a variety of uses some of which are listed here.
===Recommendations as to use===
It has been recommended based on simulation studies<ref name=Clark1994>Clark SJ & Perry JN (1994) Small sample estimation for Taylor's power law. Environment Ecol Stats 1 (4) 287–302, {{doi|10.1007/BF00469426}}</ref> in applications testing the validity of Taylor's law to a data sample that:
(1) the total number of organisms studied be > 15<br/> (2) the minimum number of groups of organisms studied be > 5<br/> (3) the density of the organisms should vary by at least 2 orders of magnitude within the sample
===Randomly distributed populations===
It is common assumed (at least initially) that a population is randomly distributed in the environment. If a population is randomly distributed then the mean ( ''m'' ) and variance ( ''s''<sup>2</sup> ) of the population are equal and the proportion of samples that contain at least one individual ( ''p'' ) is
: <math> p = 1 - e^{ -m } </math>
When a species with a clumped pattern is compared with one that is randomly distributed with equal overall densities, p will be less for the species having the clumped distribution pattern. Conversely when comparing a uniformly and a randomly distributed species but at equal overall densities, ''p'' will be greater for the randomly distributed population. This can be graphically tested by plotting ''p'' against ''m''.
Wilson and Room developed a binomial model that incorporates Taylor's law.<ref name=Wison1983>Wilson LT & Room PM (1983) Clumping patterns of fruit and arthropods in cotton with implications for binomial sampling. Environ Entomol 12:50-54</ref> The basic relationship is
: <math> p = 1 - e^{ - m \log( s^2 / m )( s^2 / m - 1 )^{ -1 } } </math>
where the log is taken to the base ''e''.
Incorporating Taylor's law this relationship becomes
: <math> p = 1 - e^{ - m \log( a m^{ b - 1 } )( a m^{ b - 1 } - 1 )^{ -1 } } </math>
===Dispersion parameter estimator===
The common dispersion parameter (''k'') of the negative binomial distribution is
: <math> k = m^2 / ( s^2 - m ) </math>
where ''m'' is the sample mean and ''s''<sup>2</sup> is the variance.<ref name=Bliss1953>Bliss CI and Fisher RA (1953) Fitting the negative binomial distribution to biological data (also includes note on the efficient fitting of the negative binomial). Biometrics 9: 177-200</ref> If 1 / ''k'' is > 0 the population is considered to be aggregated; 1 / ''k'' = 0 ( ''s''<sup>2</sup> = ''m'' ) the population is considered to be randomly (Poisson) distributed and if 1 / ''k'' is < 0 the population is considered to be uniformly distributed. No comment on the distribution can be made if ''k'' = 0.
Wilson and Room assuming that Taylor's law applied to the population gave an alternative estimator for ''k'':<ref name="Wison1983"/>
: <math> k = \frac { m } { a m^{ b - 1 } - 1 } </math>
where ''a'' and ''b'' are the constants from Taylor's law.
Jones<ref name=Jones1991>Jones VP (1991) Binomial sampling plans for tentiform leafminer (Lepidoptera: Gracillariidae) on apple in Utah. J Econ Entomol 84: 484-488</ref> using the estimate for ''k'' above along with the relationship Wilson and Room developed for the probability of finding a sample having at least one individual<ref name="Wison1983"/>
: <math> p = 1 - e^{ - m \log( a m^{ b - 1 } )( a m^{ b - 1 } - 1 )^{ -1 } } </math>
derived an estimator for the probability of a sample containing ''x'' individuals per sampling unit. Jones's formula is
: <math> P( x ) = P( x - 1 ) \frac { k + x - 1 } { x } \frac { m k^{ -1 } } { m k^{ -1 } - 1 } </math>
where ''P''( ''x'' ) is the probability of finding ''x'' individuals per sampling unit, ''k'' is estimated from the Wilon and Room equation and ''m'' is the sample mean. The probability of finding zero individuals ''P''( 0 ) is estimated with the [[negative binomial distribution]]
: <math> P( 0 ) = ( 1 + m / k )^{ -k } </math>
Jones also gives confidence intervals for these probabilities.
: <math> \mathrm{ CI } = t \left( \frac { P( x ) ( 1 - P( x ) ) } { N } \right)^{ 1 / 2 } </math>
where ''CI'' is the confidence interval, ''t'' is the critical value taken from the t distribution and ''N'' is the total sample size.
===Katz family of distributions===
Katz proposed a family of distributions (the [[Katz family]]) with 2 parameters ( ''w''<sub>1</sub>, ''w''<sub>2</sub> ).<ref name=Katz1965>Katz L (1965) United treatment of a broad class of discrete probability distributions. ''in'' Proceedings of the International Symposium on Discrete Distributions. Montreal</ref> This family of distributions includes the [[Bernoulli distribution|Bernoulli]], [[Geometric distribution|Geometric]], [[Pascal distribution|Pascal]] and Poisson distributions as special cases. The mean and variance of a Katz distribution are
: <math> m = \frac { w_1 } { 1 - w_2 } </math>
: <math> s^2 = \frac{ w_1 } { ( 1 - w_2 )^2 } </math>
where ''m'' is the mean and ''s''<sup>2</sup> is the variance of the sample. The parameters can be estimated by the method of moments from which we have
: <math> \frac { w_1 } { ( 1 - w_2 ) } = m </math>
: <math> \frac { w_2 } { ( 1 - w_2 ) } = \frac { s^2 - m } { m } </math>
For a Poisson distribution ''w''<sub>2</sub> = 0 and ''w''<sub>1</sub> = ''λ'' the parameter of the Possion distribution. This family of distributions is also sometimes known as the Panjer family of distributions.
The Katz family is related to the Sundt-Jewel family of distributions:<ref name=Jewel1981>Jewel W, Sundt B (1981) Improved approximations for the distribution of a heterogeneous risk portfolio. Bull Assoc Swiss Act 81: 221-240</ref>
<math> p_n = \left( a + \frac{ b }{ n } \right) p_{ n - 1 } </math>
The only members of the Sundt-Jewel family are the Poisson, binomial, negative binomial (Pascal), [[extended truncated negative binomial]] and [[logarithmic series distribution]]s.
If the population obeys a Katz distribution then the coefficients of Taylor's law are
: <math> a = -\log ( 1 - w_2 ) </math>
: <math> b = 1 </math>
Katz also introduced a statistical test<ref name="Katz1965"/>
: <math> J_n = \sqrt { \frac { n } { 2 } } \frac { s^2 - m } { m } </math>
where ''J''<sub>n</sub> is the test statistic, ''s''<sup>2</sup> is the variance of the sample, ''m'' is the mean of the sample and ''n'' is the sample size. ''J''<sub>n</sub> is asymptotically normally distributed with a zero mean and unit variance. If the sample is Poisson distributed ''J''<sub>n</sub> = 0; values of ''J''<sub>n</sub> < 0 and > 0 indicate under and over dispersion respectively. Overdispersion is often caused by latent heterogeneity - the presence of multiple sub populations within the population the sample is drawn from.
This statistic is related to the Neyman-Scott statistic
: <math> NS = \sqrt { \frac { n - 1 } { 2 } } \left( \frac { s^2} { m } - 1 \right) </math>
which is known to be asymptotically normal and the conditional chi-squared statistic (Poisson dispersion test)
: <math> T = \frac { ( n - 1 ) s^2 } { m } </math>
which is known to have an asymptotic chi squared distribution with ''n'' − 1 degrees of freedom when the population is Poisson distributed.
If the population obeys Taylor's law then
: <math> J_n = \sqrt { \frac { n } { 2 } } ( a m^{ b - 1 } - 1 ) </math>
===Time to extinction===
If Taylor's law is assumed to apply it is possible to determine the mean time to local extinction. This model assumes a simple random walk in time and the absence of density dependent population regulation.<ref name=Foley1994>Foley P (1994) Predicting extinction times from environmental stochasticity and carrying capacity. Conserv Biol 8: 124-137</ref>
Let <math> N_{ t + 1 } = r N_{ t } </math> where ''N''<sub>t+1</sub> and ''N''<sub>t</sub> are the population sizes at time ''t'' + 1 and ''t'' respectively and ''r'' is parameter equal to the annual increase (decrease in population). Then
: <math> var(r) = s^2 ( \log( r ) ) </math>
where ''var''( ''r'' ) is the variance of ''r''.
Let ''K'' be a measure of the species abundance (organisms per unit area). Then
: <math> T_E = \frac{ 2\log( N ) } { Var( r ) } ( \log( K ) - \frac{ \log( N ) } { 2 }) </math>
where T<sub>E</sub> is the mean time to local extinction.
The probability of extinction by time ''t'' is
: <math> P( t ) = 1 - e^{ \frac{ t } { T_E } } </math>
===Minimum population size required to avoid extinction===
If a population is [[lognormal distribution|lognormally distributed]] then the [[harmonic mean]] of the population size (''H'') is related to the [[arithmetic mean]] (''m'')<ref name=Pertoldi2008>Pertoldi C, Bach LA, Loeschcke V (2008) On the brink between extinction and persistence. Biol Direct 3: 47 doi: 10.1186/1745-6150-3-47</ref>
: <math> H = m - am^{ ( b - 1 ) } </math>
Given that ''H'' must be > 0 for the population to persist then rearranging we have
: <math> m > a^{ \frac{ 1 }{ 2 - b } } </math>
is the minimum size of population for the species to persist.
The assumption of a lognormal distribution appears to apply to about half of a sample of 544 species.<ref name=Halley2002>Halley J, Inchausti P (2002) Lognormality in ecological time series. Oikos 99:518–530. doi: 10.1034/j.1600-0706.2002.11962.x</ref> suggesting that it is at least a plausible assumption.
===Sampling size estimators===
The degree of precision (''D'') is defined to be ''s'' / ''m'' where ''s'' is the [[standard deviation]] and ''m'' is the mean. The degree of precision is known as the [[coefficient of variation]] in other contexts. In ecology research it is recommended that ''D'' be in the range 10-25%.<ref name=Southwood2000>Southwood TRE & Henderson PA (2000) Ecological methods. 3rd ed. Blackwood, Oxford</ref> The desired degree of precision is important in estimating the required sample size where an investigator wishes to test if Taylor's law applies to the data. The required sample size has been estimated for a number of simple distributions but where the population distribution is not known or cannot be assumed more complex formulae may needed to determine the required sample size.
Where the population is Poisson distributed the sample size (''n'') needed is
: <math> n = ( t / D )^2 / m </math>
where ''t'' is critical level of the [[Student's t-distribution|t distribution]] for the type 1 error with the [[degrees of freedom (statistics)|degrees of freedom]] that the mean (''m'') was calculated with.
If the population is distributed as a [[negative binomial distribution]] then the required sample size is
: <math> n = ( t / D )^2 ( m + k ) / ( mk ) </math>
where ''k'' is the parameter of the negative binomial distribution.
A more general sample size estimator has also been proposed<ref name=Service1971>Service MW (1971) Studies on sampling larval populations of the ''Anopheles gambiae'' complex. Bull World Health Organ 45: 169-180</ref>
: <math> n = ( t / D )^2 a m^{( b - 2 )} </math>
where a and b are derived from Taylor's law.
An alternative has been proposed by Southwood<ref name=Southwood1978>Southwood TRE (1978) Ecological methods. Chapman & Hall, London, England</ref>
: <math> n = a m^b / D^2 \, </math>
where ''n'' is the required sample size, ''a'' and ''b'' are the Taylor's law coefficients and ''D'' is the desired degree of precision.
Karandinos proposed two similar estimators for ''n''.<ref name=Karandinos1976>Karandinos MG (1976) Optimum sample size and comments on some published formulae. Bull Entomol Soc Am 22:417-421</ref> The first was modified by Ruesink to incorporate Taylor's law.<ref name=Ruesink1980>Ruesink WG (1980) Introduction to sampling theory, in Kogan M & Herzog DC (eds.) Sampling Methods in Soybean Entomology. Springer-Verlag New York, Inc, New York. pp 61-78</ref>
: <math> n = ( t / d_m )^2 a m^{( b - 2 )} </math>
where ''d'' is the ratio of half the desired confidence interval (''CI'') to the mean. In symbols
: <math> d_m = \frac { CI } { 2m } </math>
The second estimator is used in binomial (presence-absence) sampling. The desired sample size (''n'') is
<math> n = ( t / d_p )^2 p^{ -1 } q </math>
where the ''d''<sub>p</sub> is ratio of half the desired confidence interval to the proportion of sample units with individuals, ''p'' is proportion of samples containing individuals and ''q'' = 1 - ''p''. In symbols
: <math> d_p = \frac { CI } { 2p } </math>
For binary (presence/absence) sampling, Schulthess ''et al'' modified Karandinos' equation
<math> N = \left( \frac{ t } { D_{ pi } } \right)^2 \frac{ 1 - p }{ p } </math>
where ''N'' is the required sample size, ''p'' is the proportion of units containing the organisms of interest, ''t'' is the chosen level of significance and ''D''<sub>ip</sub> is a parameter derived from Taylor's law.<ref name=Schulthess1991>Schulthess F, Bosque-Péreza NA, Gounoua S (1991) Sampling lepidopterous pests on maize in West Africa. Bull Entomol Res 81 (3) 297-301</ref>
===Sequential sampling===
[[Sequential analysis]] is a method of [[statistical analysis]] where the sample size is not fixed in advance. Instead samples are taken in accordance with a predefined [[stopping rule]]. Taylor's law has been used to derive a number of stopping rules.
A formula for fixed precision in serial sampling to test Taylor's law was derived by Green in 1970.<ref name=Bisseleua2011>Bisseleua DHB, Yede, & Vida S (2011) Dispersion models and sampling of cacao mirid bug ''Sahlbergella singularis'' (Hemiptera: Miridae) on theobroma cacao in southern Cameroon. Environ Entomol 40(1): 111-119</ref>
: <math> \log T = \frac{\log ( D^2 ) - a }{ b - 2 } + (\log n) \frac{ b - 1 }{ b - 2 } </math>
where ''T'' is the cumulative sample total, ''D'' is the level of precision, ''n'' is the sample size and ''a'' and ''b'' are obtained from Taylor's law.
As an aid to pest control Wilson ''et al'' developed a test that incorporated a threshold level where action should be taken.<ref name=Wilson1985>Wilson LT, Gonzalez D & Plant RE(1985) Predicting sampling frequency and economic status of spider mites on cotton. Proc. Beltwide Cotton Prod Res Conf, National Cotton Council of America, Memphis, TN pp 168-170</ref> The required sample size is
: <math> n = t | m - T |^{ - 2} a m^b </math>
where ''a'' and ''b'' are the Taylor coefficients, || is the [[absolute value]], ''m'' is the sample mean, ''T'' is the threshold level and ''t'' is the critical level of the t distribution. The authors also provided a similar test for binomial (presence-absence) sampling
: <math> n = t | m - T |^{ -2 } p q </math>
where ''p'' is the probability of finding a sample with pests present and ''q'' = 1 - ''p''.
Green derived another sampling formula for sequential sampling based on Taylor's law<ref name=Green1970>Green RH (1970) On fixed precision level sequential sampling. Res Pop Ecol 12 (2) 249-251 {{doi|10.1007/BF02511568}}</ref>
: <math> D = ( a n^{ 1 - b } T^{ b - 2 } )^ { 1 / 2 } </math>
where ''D'' is the degree of precision, ''a'' and ''b'' are the Taylor's law coefficients, ''n'' is the sample size and ''T'' is the total number of individuals sampled.
Serra ''et al'' have proposed a stopping rule based on Taylor's law.<ref name=Serraa2012>Serraa GV, La Porta NC, Avalos S, Mazzuferi V (2012) Fixed-precision sequential sampling plans for estimating alfalfa caterpillar, ''Colias lesbia'', egg density in alfalfa, ''Medicago sativa'', fields in Córdoba, Argentina. J Insect Sci 13: 41</ref>
<math> T_n \ge \left( \frac{ a n^{ 1 - b } }{ D^2 } \right)^{ \frac{ 1 } { 2 - b } } </math>
where ''a'' and ''b'' are the parameters from Taylor's law, ''D'' is the desired level of precision and ''T''<sub>n</sub> is the total sample size.
Serra ''et al'' also proposed a second stopping rule based on Iwoa's regression
<math> T_n \ge \frac{ \alpha - 1 }{ D^2 - \frac{ \beta - 1 }{ n } }</math>
where ''α'' and ''β'' are the parameters of the regression line, ''D'' is the desired level of precision and ''T''<sub>n</sub> is the total sample size.
The authors recommended that ''D'' be set at 0.1 for studies of population dynamics and ''D'' = 0.25 for pest control.
==Related analyses==
It is considered to be good practice to estimate at least one additional analysis of aggregation (other than Taylor's law) because the use of only a single index may be misleading.<ref name=Myers1978>Myers JH (1978). Selecting a measure of dispersion. Environ Entomol 7: 619–621</ref> Although a number of other methods for detecting relationships between the variance and mean in biological samples have been proposed, to date none have achieved the popularity of Taylor's law. The most popular analysis used in conjunction with Taylor's law is probably Iowa's Patchiness regression test but all the methods listed here have been used in the literature.
===Barlett–Iawo model===
Barlett in 1936<ref name=Bartlett1936 /> and later Iawo independently in 1968<ref name=Iwao1968a>Iwao S (1968) A new regression method for analyzing the aggregation pattern of animal populations. Res Popul Ecol 10: 1–20</ref> both proposed an alternative relationship between the variance and the mean. In symbols
: <math> s_i^2 = am_i + bm_i^2 \, </math>
where ''s'' is the variance in the ''i''th sample and ''m''<sub>''i''</sub> is the mean of the ''i''th sample
When the population follows a [[negative binomial distribution]], ''a'' = 1 and ''b'' = ''k'' (the exponent of the negative binomial distribution).
This alternative formulation has not been found to be as good a fit as Taylor's law in most studies.
===Nachman model===
Nachman proposed a relationship between the mean density and the proportion of samples with zero counts:<ref name=Nachman1981>Nachman G (1981) A mathematical model of the functional relationship between density and spatial distribution of a population. J Anim Ecol 50: 453–460</ref>
: <math> p_0 = \exp( -a m^b ) </math>
where ''p''<sub>0</sub> is the proportion of the sample with zero counts, ''m'' is the mean density, ''a'' is a scale parameter and ''b'' is a dispersion parameter. If ''a'' = ''b'' = 0 the distribution is random. This relationship is usually tested in its logarithmic form
: <math> \log m = c + d \log p_0 </math>
Allsop used this relationship along with Taylor's law to derive an expression for the proportion of infested units in a sample<ref name=Allsopp1991>Allsopp PG (1991) Binomial sequential sampling of adult ''Saccharicoccus sacchari'' on sugarcane. Entomologia Experimentalis et Applicata 60 (3) 213–218</ref>
: <math> P_1 = 1 - \exp\left( -\exp\left( \frac{ \frac{ \log_e \left( \frac{ A^2 } a \right) }{ b - 2 } + \log_e( n )\left( \frac{ b - 1 }{ b - 2 } - 1 \right) - c } d \right) \right)</math>
: <math> N = n P_1 </math>
where
: <math> A^2 = \frac{D^2}{z^2_{\alpha/2}} </math>
where ''D''<sup>2</sup> is the degree of precision desired, ''z''<sub>α/2</sub> is the upper α/2 of the normal distribution, ''a'' and ''b'' are the Taylor's law coefficients, ''c'' and ''d'' are the Nachman coefficients, ''n'' is the sample size and ''N'' is the number of infested units.
===Kono–Sugino equation===
Binary sampling is not uncommonly used in ecology. In 1958 Kono and Sugino derived an equation that relates the proportion of samples without individuals to the mean density of the samples.<ref name=Kono1958>Kono T & Sugino T (1958) On the estimation of density of rice stem infested by the rice stem borer. Japanese J Appl Entomol and Zool 2: 184</ref>
: <math> \log( m ) = \log( a ) + b \log( - \log( p_0 ) ) </math>
where ''p''<sub>0</sub> is the proportion of the sample with no individuals, ''m'' is the mean sample density, ''a'' and ''b'' are constants. Like Taylor's law this equation has been found to fit a variety of populations including ones that obey Taylor's law. Unlike the negative binomial distribution this model is independent of the mean density.
The derivation of this equation is straightforward. Let the proportion of empty units be ''p''<sub>0</sub> and assume that these are distributed exponentially. Then
<math> p_0 = \exp( -A m^B ) </math>
Taking logs twice and re arranging, we obtain the equation above. This model is the same as that proposed by Nachman.
The advantage of this model is that it does not require counting the individuals but rather their presence or absence. Counting individuals may not be possible in many cases particularly where insects are the matter of study.
;Note
The equation was derived while examining the relationship between the proportion ''P'' of a series of rice hills infested and the mean severity of infestation ''m''. The model studied was
: <math> P = 1 - a e^{ b m } </math>
where ''a'' and ''b'' are empirical constants. Based on this model the constants ''a'' and ''b'' were derived and a table prepared relating the values of ''P'' and ''m''
;Uses
The predicted estimates of ''m'' from this equation are subject to bias<ref name=Binns1990>Binns MR & Bostonian NJ (1990) Robustness in empirically based binomial decision rules for integrated pest management. J Econ Entomol 83: 420–442</ref> and it is recommended that the adjusted mean ( ''m''<sub>a</sub> ) be used instead<ref name=Nachman1984>Nachman G (1984) Estimates of mean population density and spatial distribution of ''Tetranychus urticae'' (Acarina: Tetranychidae) and ''Phytoseiulus persimilis'' (Acarina: Phytoseiidae) based upon the proportion of empty sampling units. ''J Appl Ecolog'' 21: 903-991</ref>
: <math> m_a = m \left( 1 - \frac { \operatorname{var}( \log( m_i ) ) } 2 \right) </math>
where var is the variance of the sample unit means ''m''<sub>''i''</sub> and ''m'' is the overall mean.
An alternative adjustment to the mean estimates is<ref name=Nachman1984/> : <math> m_a = m e^{ ( \text{MSE} / 2 ) } </math>
where MSE is the mean square error of the regression.
This model may also be used to estimate stop lines for enumerative (sequential) sampling. The variance of the estimated means is<ref name=Schaalje1991>Schaalje GB, Butts RA, Lysyk TL (1991) Simulation studies of binomial sampling: a new variance estimator and density pre&ctor, with special reference to the Russian wheat aphid (Homoptera: Aphididae). J Econ Entomol 84: 140–147</ref>
: <math> \operatorname{var}( m ) = m^2 ( c_1 + c_2 - c_3 + MSE ) </math>
where
: <math> c_1 = \frac{ \beta^2 ( 1 - p_0 ) }{ n p_0 \log_e( p_0 )^2 } </math>
: <math> c_2 = \frac{ \text{MSE} } { N } + s_{\beta}^2 ( \log_e( \log_e( p_0 ) ) - p^2 ) </math>
: <math> c_3 = \frac{ \exp( a + ( b - 2 )[\alpha - \beta \log_e( p_0 ) ] ) } n </math>
where MSE is the [[mean square error]] of the regression, ''α'' and ''β'' are the constant and slope of the regression respectively, ''s''<sub>β</sub><sup>2</sup> is the variance of the slope of the regression, ''N'' is the number of points in the regression, ''n'' is the number of sample units and ''p'' is the mean value of ''p''<sub>0</sub> in the regression. The parameters ''a'' and ''b'' are estimated from Taylor's law:
: <math> s^2 = a + b \log_e( m ) </math>
===Hughes–Madden equation===
Hughes and Madden have proposed testing a similar relationship applicable to binary observations in cluster, where each cluster contains from 0 to n individuals.<ref name="Hughes&Madden1992"/>
: <math> var_\text{obs} = a p^b ( 1 - p )^c </math>
where ''a'', ''b'' and ''c'' are constants, ''var<sub>obs</sub>'' is the observed variance, and p is the proportion of individuals with a trait (such as disease), an estimate of the probability of an individual with a trait. In logarithmic form, this relationship is
: <math> \log( \operatorname{var}_\text{obs} ) = \log( a ) + b \log( p ) + c \log( 1 - p ) .</math>
In most cases, it is assumed that ''b = c'', leading to a simple model
: <math> \operatorname{var}_\text{obs} = a ( p( 1 - p ) )^b </math>
This relationship has been subjected to less extensive testing than Taylor's law. However, it has accurately described over 100 data sets, and there are no published examples reporting that it does not works.<ref name="Turechek et al.2011"/>
A variant of this equation was proposed by Shiyomi et al. (<ref name=Shiyomi1998>Shiyomi M, Egawa T, Yamamoto Y (1998) Negative hypergeometric series and Taylor's power law in occurrence of plant populations in semi-natural grassland in Japan. Proceedings of the 18th International Grassland Congress on grassland management. The Inner Mongolia Univ Press pp 35–43 (1998)</ref>) who suggested testing the regression
: <math> \log( \operatorname{var}_\text{obs} / n^2 ) = a + b \log( p ( 1 - p ) / n ) </math>
where var<sub>obs</sub> is the variance, ''a'' and ''b'' are the constants of the regression, ''n'' here is the sample size (not sample per cluster) and ''p'' is the probability of a sample containing at least one individual.
===Negative binomial distribution model===
A negative binomial model has also been proposed.<ref name=Wilson1983>Wilson L T & Room PM (1983) Clumping patterns of fruit and arthropods in cotton, with implications for binomial sampling. Environ Entomol 12: 50–54</ref> The dispersion parameter (''k'') using the method of moments is ''m''<sup>2</sup> / ( ''s''<sup>2</sup> – ''m'' ) and ''p''<sub>''i''</sub> is the proportion of samples with counts > 0. The ''s''<sup>2</sup> used in the calculation of ''k'' are the values predicted by Taylor's law. ''p''<sub>''i''</sub> is plotted against 1 - ( ''k'' ( ''k'' + ''m'' ) <sup>−1</sup> )<sup>''k''</sup> and the fit of the data is visually inspected.
Perry and Taylor have proposed an alternative estimator of ''k'' based on Taylor's law.<ref name=Perry1986>Perry JN & Taylor LR(1986). Stability of real interacting populations in space and time: implications, alternatives and negative binomial. J Animal Ecol 55: 1053–1068</ref>
: <math> 1/k = am^{ b - 2 } - 1 / m</math>
A better estimate of the dispersion parameter can be made with the method of [[maximum likelihood]]. For the negative binomial it can be estimated from the equation<ref name="Bliss1953"/>
: <math> \sum \frac { A_x } { k + x } = N \log( 1 + m / k ) </math>
where ''A''<sub>''x''</sub> is the total number of samples with more than ''x'' individuals, ''N'' is the total number of individuals, ''x'' is the number of individuals in a sample, ''m'' is the mean number of individuals per sample and ''k'' is the exponent. The value of ''k'' has to be estimated numerically.
Goodness of fit of this model can be tested in a number of ways including using the chi square test. As these may be biased by small samples an alternative is the ''U'' statistic – the difference between the variance expected under the negative binomial distribution and that of the sample. The expected variance of this distribution is ''m'' + ''m''<sup>2</sup> / ''k'' and
: <math> U = s^2 - m + m^2 / k </math>
where ''s''<sup>2</sup> is the sample variance, ''m'' is the sample mean and ''k'' is the negative binomial parameter.
The variance of U is<ref name="Bliss1953"/>
: <math> \operatorname{var}( U ) = 2m p^2 q \left( \frac { 1 - R^2 } {-\log( 1 - R ) - R } \right) + p^4 \frac { (1 - R)^{-k} - 1 - kR } { N ( -\log( 1 - R ) - R)^2 } </math>
where ''p'' = ''m'' / ''k'', ''q'' = 1 + ''p'', ''R'' = ''p'' / ''q'' and ''N'' is the total number of individuals in the sample. The expected value of ''U'' is 0. For large sample sizes ''U'' is distributed normally.
Note: The negative binomial is actually a family of distributions defined by the relation of the mean to the variance
<math> \sigma^2 = \mu + a \mu^p </math>
where ''a'' and ''p'' are constants. When ''a'' = 0 this defines the Poisson distribution. With ''p'' = 1 and ''p'' = 2, the distribution is known as the NB1 and NB2 distribution respectively.
This model is a version of that proposed earlier by Barlett.
===Tests for a common dispersion parameter===
The dispersion parameter (''k'')<ref name="Bliss1953"/> is
: <math> k = m^2 / ( s^2 - m ) </math>
where ''m'' is the sample mean and ''s''<sup>2</sup> is the variance. If ''k''<sup>−1</sup> is > 0 the population is considered to be aggregated; ''k''<sup>−1</sup> = 0 the population is considered to be random; and if ''k''<sup>−1</sup> is < 0 the population is considered to be uniformly distributed.
Southwood has recommended regressing ''k'' against the mean and a constant<ref name=Southwood1978 />
: <math> k_i = a + b m_i </math>
where ''k''<sub>''i''</sub> and ''m''<sub>''i''</sub> are the dispersion parameter and the mean of the ith sample respectively to test for the existence of a common dispersion parameter (''k''<sub>''c''</sub>). A slope (''b'') value significantly > 0 indicates the dependence of ''k'' on the mean density.
An alternative method was proposed by Elliot who suggested plotting ( ''s''<sup>2</sup> − ''m'' ) against ( ''m''<sup>2</sup> − ''s''<sup>2</sup> / ''n'' ).<ref name=Elliot1977a>Elliot JM (1977) Some methods for the statistical analysis of samples of benthic invertebrates. 2nd ed. Freshwater Biological Association, Cambridge, United Kingdom</ref> ''k''<sub>''c''</sub> is equal to 1/slope of this regression.
===Charlier coefficient===
This coefficient (''C'') is defined as
<math> C = \frac{ 100 ( s^2 - m )^{0.5} } { m } </math>
If the population can be assumed to be distributed in a negative binomial fashion, then ''C'' = 100 (1/''k'')<sup>0.5</sup> where ''k'' is the dispersion parameter of the distribution.
===Cole's index of dispersion===
This index (''I''<sub>c</sub>) is defined as<ref name=Cole1946>Cole LC (1946) A theory for analyzing contagiously distributed populations. Ecol 27: 329–341</ref>
: <math> I_c = \frac{ \Sigma x^2 }{ ( \Sigma x )^2 } </math>
The usual interpretation of this index is as follows: values of ''I''<sub>c</sub> < 1, 1, > 1 are taken to mean a uniform distribution, a random distribution or an aggregated distribution.
Because ''s''<sup>2</sup> = Σ x<sup>2</sup> − (Σx)<sup>2</sup>, the index can also be written
: <math> I_c = \frac{ s^2 + ( nm )^2 }{ ( nm )^2 } = \frac{ 1 }{ n^2} \frac{ s^2 }{ m^2 } + 1 </math>
If Taylor's law can be assumed to hold, then
: <math> I_c = \frac{ a m^{ b - 2 } }{ n^2 } + 1 </math>
===Lloyd's indexes===
Lloyd's index of mean crowding (''IMC'') is the average number of other points contained in the sample unit that contains a randomly chosen point.<ref name=Lloyd1967>Lloyd M (1967) Mean crowding. J Anim Ecol 36: 1–30</ref>
: <math> \mathrm{ IMC } = m + s^2 / m - 1 </math>
where ''m'' is the sample mean and ''s''<sup>2</sup> is the variance.
Lloyd's index of patchiness (''IP'')<ref name="Lloyd1967"/> is
: <math> \mathrm{ IP } = \text{IMC} / m </math>
It is a measure of pattern intensity that is unaffected by thinning (random removal of points). This index was also proposed by Pielou in 1988 and is sometimes known by this name also.
Because an estimate of the variance of ''IP'' is extremely difficult to estimate from the formula itself, LLyod suggested fitting a negative binomial distribution to the data. This method gives a parameter ''k''
: <math> s^2 = m + \frac{ m^2 }{ k } </math>
Then
: <math> SE( IP ) = \frac{ 1 }{ k^2 } [ \operatorname{var}( k ) + \frac{ k ( k + 1 ) ( k + m ) }{ mq } ] </math>
where ''SE''(''IP'') is the standard error of the index of patchiness,''var''(''k'') is the variance of the parameter ''k'' and ''q'' is the number of [[quadrat]]s sampled..
If the population obeys Taylor's law then
: <math> \mathrm{ IMC } = m + a^{ -1 } m^{ 1 - b } - 1 </math>
: <math> \mathrm{ IP } = 1 + a^{ -1 } m^{ - b } - \frac { 1 } { m } </math>
===Patchiness regression test===
Iwao proposed a patchiness regression to test for clumping<ref name=Iwao1968b>Iwao S & Kuno E (1968) Use of the regression of mean crowding on mean density for estimating sample size and the transformation of data for the analysis of variance.
